Description: surface pressure (not mean sea-level pressure), 2-D field to calculate the 3-D pressure field from hybrid coordinates
Comment: not, in general, the same as mean sea-level pressure

Description: Temperature of the lower boundary of the atmosphere
Comment: Surface temperature (skin for open ocean)

Description: Percentage of grid cell covered by sea ice
Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.
Comment: for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Include both large-scale and convective cloud.

Description: Convective cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes only convective cloud.
Comment: Convective cloud fraction

Description: The optical thickness is the integral along the path of radiation of a volume scattering/absorption/attenuation coefficient. The radiative flux is reduced by a factor exp(-optical_thickness) on traversing the path. A coordinate variable of radiation_wavelength or radiation_frequency can be specified to indicate that the optical thickness applies at specific wavelengths or frequencies. The atmosphere optical thickness applies to radiation passing through the entire atmosphere. "Cloud" means the component of extinction owing to the presence of liquid or ice water particles. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase.
2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature
2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature
2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature
includes both liquid and solid phases
Comment: at surface; includes both liquid and solid phases from all types of clouds (both large-scale and convective)

Description: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.
Comment: includes both evaporation and sublimation

Description: The surface sensible heat flux, also called turbulent heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air.
at the top of the atmosphere
at the top of the atmosphere (to be compared with satellite measurements)
Total ozone column calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU.
Comment: total ozone column in DU

Description: Calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU.
Comment: Tropospheric ozone column, should be consistent with definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp).

Long name: Monthly Photochemical Loss of O3strat Tracer
Description: Monthly average of the vertical integral of the imposed chemical loss for the stratospheric ozone tracer o3strat reported as a two-dimensional (latitude-longitude) field. Following the definition of o3strat, there should only be non-zero contributions to the integral between the surface and the locally diagnosed tropopause. Assume a molecular weight for o3strat of 0.048 kg mol-1.
Comment: Please use the opposite sign convention of the actual physical process. A negative tendency or loss is reported as a positive number.

Long name: Dry Deposition Rate of O3strat Tracer
Description: Following the definition of o3strat, this is the dry deposition flux of O3strat to the surface assuming the deposition velocity of O3strat is equal to that calculated for ozone. Assume a molecular weight of o3strat of 0.048 kg mol-1.
Comment: Please report the flux toward the surface as a positive number.

Description: Air Temperature

Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.
Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).
Meridional wind (positive in a northward direction).

A velocity is a vector quantity. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). Upward air velocity is the vertical component of the 3D air velocity vector. The standard name downward_air_velocity may be used for a vector component with the opposite sign convention.
Percentage cloud cover, including both large-scale and convective cloud.
Comment: Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

Description: Include only convective cloud.

In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics. The atmosphere convective mass flux is the vertical transport of mass for a field of cumulus clouds or thermals, given by the product of air density and vertical velocity. For an area-average, cell_methods should specify whether the average is over all the area or the area of updrafts only.
Comment: Calculated as the convective mass flux divided by the area of the whole grid cell (not just the area of the cloud).

Long name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Longwave Radiative Heating
Description: Tendency of air temperature due to longwave radiative heating
Comment: longwave heating rates

Long name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Shortwave Radiative Heating
Description: Tendency of air temperature due to shortwave radiative heating
Comment: shortwave heating rates

Description: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Gas phase only.
The mean age of air is defined as the mean time that a stratospheric air mass has been out of contact with the well-mixed troposphere.

Long name: Stratospheric Ozone Tracer Volume Mixing Ratio
Description: Tracer to estimate contribution of stratospheric ozone to ozone in the troposphere. Set to ozone in the stratosphere, then destroyed in the troposphere using the Ox chemical loss frequency calculated from the sum of losses by the three reactions O1D+H2O, OH+O3 and HO2+O3. The tracer should dry deposit at the surface with the dry deposition velocity of ozone. Please specify the tropopause definition used.
Comment: Ozone tracer intended to map out contribution of stratospheric ozone to ozone in the troposphere.

Long name: Total Reactive Nitrogen Volume Mixing Ratio
Description: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model); list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. NOy = N + NO + NO2 + NO3 + HNO3 + 2N2O5 + HNO4 + ClONO2 + BrONO2 Definition: Total reactive nitrogen; usually includes atomic nitrogen (N), nitric oxide (NO), NO2, nitrogen trioxide (NO3), dinitrogen radical (N2O5), nitric acid (HNO3), peroxynitric acid (HNO4), BrONO2, ClONO2 add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

Long name: Total Inorganic Chlorine Volume Mixing Ratio
Description: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Cly = HCl + ClONO2 + HOCl + ClO + Cl + 2*Cl2O2 +2Cl2 + OClO + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic stratospheric chlorine (e.g., HCl, ClO) resulting from degradation of chlorine-containing source gases (CFCs, HCFCs, VSLS), and natural inorganic chlorine sources (e.g., sea salt and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

Long name: Total Inorganic Bromine Volume Mixing Ratio
Description: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Bry = Br + BrO + HOBr + HBr + BrONO2 + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic bromine (e.g., HBr and inorganic bromine oxides and radicals (e.g., BrO, atomic bromine (Br), bromine nitrate (BrONO2)) resulting from degradation of bromine-containing organic source gases (halons, methyl bromide, VSLS), and natural inorganic bromine sources (e.g., volcanoes, sea salt, and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

Mole fraction is used in the construction "mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y", where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as "nitrogen" or a phrase such as "nox_expressed_as_nitrogen". The chemical formula for carbonyl sulfide is COS. The IUPAC name for carbonyl sulfide is carbon oxide sulfide.

Long name: Surface Area Density of Sulfate Aerosol
Description: Sulfate aerosol surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1). This is the total sulfate SAD (i.e., sum of binary and ternary aerosol).

Long name: Surface Area Density of NAT PSC Particles
Description: Nitric Acid Trihydrate (NAT) surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).

Long name: Surface Area Density of Water Ice PSC Particles
Description: Water-ice surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).

Long name: Upward Component of the Eliassen-Palm Flux
Description: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics Meridional component Fz of the Eliassen-Palm (EP) flux (Fy, Fz) derived from 6hr or higher frequency fields (use daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr are not available). Please use the definitions given by equation 3.5.3b of Andrews, Holton and Leovy text book, but scaled by density to have units m3 s-2.

Long name: Northward Component of the Eliassen-Palm Flux
Description: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics Meridional component Fy of Eliassen-Palm (EP) flux (Fy, Fz) derived from 6hr or higher frequency fields (use daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr are not available). Please use the definitions given by equation 3.5.3a of Andrews, Holton and Leovy text book, but scaled by density to have units m3 s-2.

Long name: Tendency of Eastward Wind Due to Eliassen-Palm Flux Divergence
Description: Tendency of the zonal mean zonal wind due to the divergence of the Eliassen-Palm flux.

Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics v*, meridional component of the residual meridional circulation (v*, w*) derived from 6 hr or higher frequency data fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available).

Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics w*, upward component of the residual meridional circulation (v*, w*) derived from 6 hr or higher frequency data fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available). Scale height: 6950 m

Long name: Eastward Acceleration Due to Gravity Wave Drag
Description: Tendency of the eastward wind by the total (orographic + nonorographic) parameterized gravity waves.

Long name: Eastward Acceleration Due to Orographic Gravity Wave Drag
Description: Tendency of the eastward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.

Long name: Upward Flux of Eastward Momentum Due to Orographic GWD
Description: Zonal orographic gravity wave stress (momentum flux), including any flux out of the top of the model (e.g., add additional level to the output file for model top. Set flux at this level to zero if nothing escapes to outer space in your model), derived either from daily means or 6hr fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available).

Long name: Eastward Acceleration Due to Non-Orographic Gravity Wave Drag
Description: Tendency of the eastward wind by parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.

Long name: Upward Flux of Eastward Momentum Due to Eastward Propogating Non-Orographic Gravity Waves
Description: Westward component of the zonal non-orographic gravity wave momentum flux, including any flux out of the top of the model (e.g., add additional level to the output file for model top. Set flux at this level to zero if nothing escapes to outer space in your model), derived either from daily means or 6hr fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available).

Long name: Upward Flux of Eastward Momentum Due to Westward Propogating Non-Orographic Gravity Waves
Description: Eastward component of the zonal non-orographic gravity wave momentum flux, including any flux out of the top of the model (e.g., add additional level to the output file for model top. Set flux at this level to zero if nothing escapes to outer space in your model), derived either from daily means or 6hr fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available).

Long name: Eastward Acceleration Due to Numerical Artefacts
Description: Other sub-grid scale/numerical zonal drag excluding that already provided for the parameterized orographic and non-ororgraphic gravity waves. This would be used to calculate the total 'diabatic drag'. Contributions to this additional drag such Rayleigh friction and diffusion that can be calculated from the monthly mean wind fields should not be included, but details (e.g. coefficients) of the friction and/or diffusion used in the model should be provided separately.
surface pressure (not mean sea-level pressure), 2-D field to calculate the 3-D pressure field from hybrid coordinates
Comment: not, in general, the same as mean sea-level pressure

Description: Air Temperature
Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).
Meridional wind (positive in a northward direction).
Omega (vertical velocity in pressure coordinates, positive downwards)
Comment: commonly referred to as "omega", this represents the vertical component of velocity in pressure coordinates (positive down)

Description: Nitric Acid Trihydrate (NAT) surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).

Long name: Surface Area Density of Water Ice PSC Particles
Description: Water-ice surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).
surface pressure (not mean sea-level pressure), 2-D field to calculate the 3-D pressure field from hybrid coordinates
Comment: Surface Pressure .. needed for vertical coordinates

Description: Surface solar irradiance for UV calculations.
Surface solar irradiance clear sky for UV calculations
at the top of the atmosphere (to be compared with satellite measurements)
Comment: at the top of the atmosphere.

Description: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.
Comment: for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

Description: where land over land, this is computed as the mean thickness of snow in the land portion of the grid cell (averaging over the entire land portion, including the snow-free fraction). Reported as 0.0 where the land fraction is 0.
cell_methods: area: mean where land time: point

Description: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.
Comment: the mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.
cell_methods: area: mean where land time: point

Description: near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature
minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute "time: min")
maximum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute "time: max")
Air Temperature
Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).

Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.

Long name: Grid-Cell Area for Atmospheric Grid Variables
Description: For atmospheres with more than 1 mesh (e.g., staggered grids), report areas that apply to surface vertical fluxes of energy.
Comment: Cell areas for any grid used to report atmospheric variables and any other variable using that grid (e.g., soil moisture content). These cell areas should be defined to enable exact calculation of global integrals (e.g., of vertical fluxes of energy at the surface and top of the atmosphere).

Description: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. Altitude is the (geometric) height above the geoid, which is the reference geopotential surface. The geoid is similar to mean sea level.
Comment: height above the geoid; as defined here, 'the geoid' is a surface of constant geopotential that, if the ocean were at rest, would coincide with mean sea level. Under this definition, the geoid changes as the mean volume of the ocean changes (e.g., due to glacial melt, or global warming of the ocean).  Reported here is the height above the present-day geoid (0.0 over ocean).

Long name: Percentage of the grid  cell occupied by land (including lakes)
Description: Percentage of horizontal area occupied by land.
Percentage of grid cell covered by land ice (ice sheet, ice shelf, ice cap, glacier)
Comment: fraction of grid cell occupied by 'permanent' ice (i.e., glaciers).

Description: Height of full model levels above a reference ellipsoid. A reference ellipsoid is a mathematical figure that approximates the geoid. The geoid is a surface of constant geopotential with which mean sea level would coincide if the ocean were at rest. The ellipsoid is an approximation because the geoid is an irregular shape. A number of reference ellipsoids are defined for use in the field of geodesy. To specify which reference ellipsoid is being used, a grid_mapping variable should be attached to the data variable as described in Chapter 5.6 of the CF Convention.
Comment: Provide only if altitude of full model levels is fixed
